cyclone.name: MATTHEW
cyclone.current_location: about 35 mi NNE of Tiburon, Haiti and 90 mi south of the eastern tip of Cuba
cyclone.trajectory: Matthew is forecast to turn N-NW, then NW, moving through the Bahamas and then paralleling the southeast U.S. coastline toward northeast Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina coasts.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: east-central Florida coast (near Cape Canaveral – Daytona Beach area)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Deerfield Beach FL to Volusia/Brevard County line (east-central Florida)
weather_observation.warning_coast: Haiti, eastern Cuba, southeastern-central-northwestern Bahamas (hurricane); Barahona DR to Haitian border & Turks and Caicos (tropical-storm)
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire southeast U.S. shoreline from Florida through Georgia and South Carolina lies within the 5-day cone
weather_observation.wind: There is a 42% chance of sustained ≥34-kt winds at Savannah, peaking late Friday night–Saturday. A 13% chance exists for ≥50-kt winds, with a small (4%) chance of hurricane-force gusts if the core tracks close to the coast.
weather_observation.storm_surge: On-shore flow ahead of Matthew could produce 3–5 ft or higher surge in the Savannah River estuary, especially during high tide Saturday.
weather_observation.rainfall: 4–6 inches of rainfall possible Saturday with localized higher totals, creating flash-flood risk in low-lying port areas.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Large battering waves, dangerous rip currents, and possible port-side power interruptions may accompany the storm; expect channel restrictions and likely temporary port closure once gale-force winds become imminent.
